text: In Greek mythology, Sthenelus (; Ancient Greek: Σθένελος Sthénelos, "strong one" or "forcer", derived from {[transl|grc|sthenos}} "strength, might, force") was one of the Achaean Leaders. He was also counted as one of the EpigoniPseudo-Apollodorus, Bibliotheca 3.7.2Hyginus, Fabulae 71 and a suitor of HelenPseudo-Apollodorus, Bibliotheca 3.10.8Hyginus, Fabulae 81. == Family == Sthenelus was the son of CapaneusHyginus, Fabulae 71, 175 & 257Pseudo- Apollodorus, Bibliotheca 3.7.2 & 3.10.8 and EvadneHyginus, Fabulae 97. He was the father of Cylarabes and Cometes, lover of AegialiaPseudo-Apollodorus, Bibliotheca Epitome of Book 4.6.9. == Mythology == Sthenelus fought alongside Diomedes and the other Argives in the Trojan War and brought 25 ships to Troy. He was one of the men who hid in the Trojan horseHyginus, Fabulae 108. In the Iliad, Sthenelus boasts that he captured the city of Thebes, while his father, fighting alongside the Seven against Thebes, was slain by a Zeus thrown thunderbolt while attempting the same thing.Homer, Iliad 4.403-410 He ruled Iphis' half of Argos, along with Diomedes, after both Adrastus and Aegialeus had died.Tripp, Edward. Crowell's Handbook of Classical Mythology.
